item.description:

Coco is a Disney/Pixar animated; Hector is a great-great-grandfather in the Land of the Dead; Coco a young girl; Remember Me a lullaby sung to her.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner 5a
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

EIHP SVHJISP, SHKV MFQ TCIS
CI.  HQO VUXYHDV HJJ 1SV
UAUVQIE. XVDHFEV HQPISCQZ
DHQ SHGGVQ. -- ECUAQV XCJVE

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

Stay healthy, have fun with it, and embrace all the moments. Because anything can happen. Simone Biles

Solving: all the, and, stay healthy

Some things I found interesting in the SB bio; she was allowed to take the ‘stimulant’ Ritalin (methylphenidate) during competition because of her ADHD. She used a dating app to meet the football player who became her husband. Her story about her sexual assault by her USA Gymnastic physician blamed not only him, but the entire ‘system’ - the association and the committee - for failing to do their jobs. That seems pretty stupid of the system; I’ll have to look further into that story.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner 5a
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

 TOQQXOJW BMXZL PXJW  PXLEL, JVJM LV UXJKMZVAL  XL YGM PXLE VD TOZYAM.  – OHGXIVU HZXJM. “LQMMFW  GVQQVB”

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

Villainy bears many masks, none so dangerous as the mask of virtue. - Ichabod Crane, “Sleepy Hollow”

Solving: none, the, as, of, dangerous, virtue

How come Washington Irving’s short story leaves us to wonder about whatever became of IC? The only two alternatives presented were that he went away and became attorney and politician OR that he was spirited away by supernatural forces; neither of which seem plausible to me. In fact, I feel that WI did a ‘bad job’ of winding up the story w/ the lout Brom Bones marrying the desirable Katrina Van Tassel.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner 5a
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

 CQQ NZCN EM TMM LV TMMY  JT UKN C AVMCY EJNZJS C  AVMCY. – MAPCV CQQCS OLM

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

All that we see or seek is but a dream within a dream. Edgar Allan Poe

Here’s the poem: https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/52829/a-dream-within-a-dream

I kinda like that one, as a non-appreciator of poetry, generally.

What I find ‘ironic’ or Poe-etic is the complete (IMO) mystery concerning the circumstances of the days before and the days of Poe’s death. That story gets a completely separate article from his bio in the wp. On top of that, some cardiologist wrote an article in a MD medical journal in ‘96 deriving the idea that Poe had died of /rabies/. That idea is more bizarre than some of the other ideas that were floated. There was no death certificate or ‘investigation’ and the doctor attending has been deemed unreliable.

I like the RC wp article, particularly how much her progress was influenced by the family financial pressures on her plans, from college on. I suspect her career would have been completely different; she would’ve gotten her PhD in zoology, become a prof, and had a completely different writing career. As it was, needing to interrupt her studies and take a job w/ the fisheries bureau provided different opportunities.

That was an interesting/ challenging one to solve. I was ‘flummoxed’ by the UD combo repeating, twice in the first word, seen again in the quote last word and the source 2nd name. The only words I could think of for the first word were ‘sense’ and ‘onion’. I wanted J>E. I liked the idea of Cookie for the first name, so I finally tried harder on onion, then ‘are’ made for rings and vegetable popped out.

Sonnet 98: From you have I been absent in the spring By William Shakespeare From you have I been absent in the spring, When proud-pied April, dressed in all his trim, Hath put a spirit of youth in everything, That heavy Saturn laughed and leaped with him. Yet nor the lays of birds, nor the sweet smell Of different flowers in odour and in hue, Could make me any summer’s story tell, Or from their proud lap pluck them where they grew: Nor did I wonder at the lily’s white, Nor praise the deep vermilion in the rose; They were but sweet, but figures of delight Drawn after you, – you pattern of all those. Yet seem’d it winter still, and, you away, As with your shadow I with these did play.

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

An American has not seen the United States until he has seen Mardi Gras in New Orleans. Mark Twain

I’ve never done MG in NOLA, but I have a nola story about a friend; well two friends, I knew them separately and dating other people before they married. She was a nurse, he studied and practiced a long time to become a plastic surgeon and started his practice of course doing a lot of breast implants. He was soon sued when there were some faulty implants which leaked. This caused /him/ to sue the implant company and they settled with him for millions and millions; and he was also relieved of the suits against him. He and his wife promptly bought an island and retired there, but missed the States, so they sold the island and moved to a nice place near the French Quarter where MG goes on.

Clearly that was about Desi in 1940.

LB died at 77 in ‘89; interesting case. Many people die ‘abruptly’ when something goes wrong w/ an aortic aneurysm. She did it a little trickier. She had chest pain, diagnosed w/ dissecting aortic aneurysm near her heart and underwent 7 hour cardio-thoracic surgery to repair the aneurysm and her aortic valve replacement. A few days later during her recovery, awoke, pain, lost consciousness and died of a ruptured abdominal aneurysm ‘unrelated’ to her surgery.

Once upon a time I had a beautiful calico cat whose heritage was that a friend rescued it as an adult from a tree and brought it home. My guess is that it had never been acculturated as a kitten, so she was never particularly warm to people, but liked to ‘hang around’ near them, not particularly to be petted or purr or cozy up. Sometimes she did crazy things. There were some sad parts about our life together.

Solving: it isn’t the, that, ahead, in your shoe

I remember the 1960 summer Olympics when 18 y/o Cassius Clay won the gold as a light heavyweight and also his defeat of Sonny Liston in ‘64. The .mil business for CC/MA was all the news back in those days, because my .us friends his age were dealing w/ the same Viet Nam draft conscription, as you reg’d for the draft at age 18 and were classified as 1A and were liable to be drafted and probably go to VN unless your classification changed for ‘something or other’. Mine was changed to 2S, the student deferment for a long time, but during that ’long time’ my draft age eligibility went up to 35 and I ultimately became an ‘obligated volunteer’.

I didn’t get Dk’s last letter G correct, but I did read about ‘his’ bridge, a pedestrian-bike bridge over the Spokane R connecting downtown Spokane w/ a uni and riverside park for Centennial Trail users. First a train bridge built in the 1920s, restored in 1988 as a Trail bridge and renamed for DK, was radically overhauled and reopened in 2022. I like parks and bridges and trails for hikers and joggers and bike riders. I was never a jogger, but I’m a current walker and I used to use a bike rack for the ‘vette and would drive somewhere ’nearby’ that was a better place to go biking.

EA Poe could put some good sounds together in a very sensible way.

We’ve seen the Chilean PN here before, rather long and interesting wp article.

Interesting ‘jury duty’ today, not from the /actual/ jd, but the processing. I’ve been thru’ that routine many times before, but this one was different. The usual process is that about a hundred or so potential jurors are called together and given info and ‘inspired’ by a video. Then everyone is told that the usual duty is 1-3 days, but it is possible to be involved in a more lengthy case and if that long time is a problem, there is another process by which one completes another questionnaire in addition to the preliminary one about being disqualified, the secondary one being about hardship of various kinds.

More than half a dozen words were reorganized by the online OCR.  I’m still baffled by how that algo is written in some vain attempt to do/perform/say something or other that it should just stay out of and perform just its proper character recognition business. When it messes up so much, it would be quicker to do it manually; alternatively use some other tool.  You can’t really tell how much time you are going to waste on the rearranging until you are in the middle of it and might as well finish that way.  It is like having an ‘able assistant’ who drops the ball every once in a while which requires doing his job all over again.  You can’t decide whether to fire him or keep doing it the same way.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner 29
item.description:

  RPKFDEI KB BKNJFZ XTI   AJJAEXDUKXZ XA YILKU   PLPKU. XTKB XKNI NAEI   KUXIFFKLIUXFZ. – TIUEZ   RAEG

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

Failure is simply the opportunity to begin again. This time more intelligently. Henry Ford

Solving: ’the’ ‘henry’ ‘opportunity to’ ‘intelligently’

HF didn’t begin again his failed idea for a rubber plantation in Brazil at Fordlandia. Brazil gave him 2.5 mil acres and no taxes in exchange for 9% of the profits. Starting in 1926 the town was founded by 1928, but wasn’t abandoned until 1934. Well, I guess you could call the move to Belterra a form of beginning again and that was a viable community, but it wasn’t until the 40s that production became economically feasible, and by then synthetic rubber had arrived. When I was looking around for more info on the Fordlandia failure, I found a more complete story at https://www.thehenryford.org/collections-and-research/digital-resources/popular-topics/brazilian-rubber-plantations/

Some things just can’t be described. and stepping onto the moon was one of them. Buzz Aldrin

Solving: -n’t ’the’ ’them’ ‘moon’ ‘Some things’

BA is frequently ‘cited’ by UFO buffs, but the true story is more mundane. That is I ‘believe’ in UFOs or UAPs, but that simply means that there are accounts which remain unexplained. I do NOT believe any aliens have visited us. I do believe that it is likely that life exists somewhere else in the universe, but that it is ’too far away’ to have anything to do w/ us. I do NOT believe in wormholes or such in the fabric of space.

NA’s medical care when he underwent quadruple bypass surgery at age 82 and subsequently died of medical complications that developed during hospital recovery was considered malpractice by his family’s attorneys. When I was studying German, I worked on reading Goethe’s Faust in an edition that had .de and .en on opposing pages. One appeal of doing something like that is that the .de is ‘better’ because the .en translator has an ‘impossible’ task in trying to be both accurate and ’literary’. That is, the reader may think, “I wouldn’t say it like that.” pretty often.

Nothing is a bigger waste of time than regretting the past and worrying about the future. James Meredith

Solving: ‘is a’ ’the’ ’than’ ‘-ing’ ‘regretting’

When I read the JM wp article, I remembered him being in the news in 1961. There was ‘plenty of’ segregation back in that day; lotsa people in segregated societies were in favor of desegregation, but felt that it was taking place ’too fast’. Naturally if one were being ‘segregated against’ one wouldn’t feel that way. However, there was also a lot of segregation of black and white which was ‘voluntary’ black segregation, perhaps because it was ’easier’ to live in a black community than not.

When I was studying German in college, the course/s was/were about reading scientific .de as opposed to conversational .de (which were my .es classes), so one style of learning for me was to have a very strong .de/.en dictionary available while reading text which had .de on one page facing the other page which had the .en translation so that one could go/ read the text/ pretty fast and only choose to look up something in the dictionary if one wanted to get a broader grasp of alternate ways of translating that same text or word or phrase. If one did enough research on a sentence, they might translate a particular passage ‘better’ than the book’s translation had provided.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner

https://www.arkansasonline.com/puzzles/quote/

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

Put your heart, mind and soul into even your smallest task. This is the secret of success. Swami Sivananda

Solving: while experimenting ‘mentally’ I spotted ‘success’ because of its repeaters and then ’this is the secret of success. The solo ‘P’ was slowest of the first sentence until I recognized the nature of the ‘instruction’.

PQ ATSJSBL FI RYHRTYH. QIN TYH RYHRTYSBL FI ATSJ.   -  PHBOTDSB AYTBWJSB

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

By failing to prepare, you are preparing to fail. Benjamin Franklin

– Mike Easter

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

I’ve made it a point never to learn my social security number because I’m a person, not a number. H. Ross Perot

Solving: ‘I’ve’ ‘a’ ’never’ ‘it’ ’to’ ‘point’ ’learn’

Reading the HRP wp article is a reminder of why …

It seems that the/his concept of a balanced budget is completely unthinkable to either of our current major parties.

– Mike Easter

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Things on the whole are much faster in America. People don’t “stand for election”; they ‘run for office." Jessica Mitford

Solving: besides ’the’ I spotted ‘people’ so it fell pretty quickly.

Because of JM, I had an opportunity to read the wp article about the ‘Mitford family’ which embraced its various members of .en aristocracy which included the ‘scandalous’ Mitford sisters.

In my college days, besides the ’tutoring business’ I had a very strange job working for a funeral home. It was interesting and I had an opportunity to read the books available in the director’s library.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

With the exception of world unrest, nothing breaks out in more places than an old garden hose. Weary gardener

There are several/ a number of/ entities that refer to themselves as ‘weary gardener’, so I wasn’t able to pin-point which of them might have been the intended source of the quote, and it didn’t seem important.

Solving: I wanted ‘??th the’, but I didn’t get far until I found ’nothing’ and ’than an’.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Home is the place where you can enjoy corn on the cob, soup and watermelon. Source unknown

Solving: ’the’ ‘ho?e is the’ ‘where’ ’enjoy’ done.

I’m still looking for the uber-long .fr report on its Catholic church sexual abuses instead of talking heads trying to tell me what it says. I don’t even care if it is in .fr; I can get google to translate it for me.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

They are slaves who fear to speak for the fallen and the weak. James Russell Lowell

Solving: ’the’ ’they’ ‘are’ ‘and’ ‘who’ ‘for’. The ’s’ was late. It seems strange to me that JL chose the word ‘slaves’ for the object of his critique; given that he was an anti-slavery activist. Curiously the wp article says…

… but doesn’t give any reference to back that up. How does your anti-slavery position ‘waver’ and what was his ‘opinion’ on African-Americans that also wavered?

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

The world has achieved brilliance without wisdom, power without conscience. Ours is a world of nuclear giants and ethical infants. Gen. Omar Bradley

Solving: I saw ‘The world has’ very early.

I recently saw the movie Patton again, of which the OB char is played by Karl Malden. The wp article on OB says:

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:

https://www.arkansasonline.com/puzzles/quote/

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

It’s easy to have principles when you’re rich. The important thing is to have principles when you’re poor. Ray A. Kroc

Solving: ‘it’s’ ’the’ ’to’ ‘you’re’ ’easy’ ‘rich’ ‘poor’ ‘principles’

The story of Ray Kroc viz the McDonald bros is interesting, as RK went from a salesman for a dying brand of milkshake mixer to franchise agent.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner

https://www.arkansasonline.com/puzzles/quote/

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

I would rather be the man who bought the Brooklyn Bridge than the man who sold it. Will Rogers

Solving: ‘I’ ’the’ ’than’ ‘rather’ ‘I would rather be’

For some reason, I’m having a hard time w/ today’s Jumble which usually only takes a few seconds. I have all the letters but not the final answer.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

https://www.arkansasonline.com/puzzles/quote/

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . My mother’s menu consisted of two choices: take it or leave it. Buddy Hackett

Solving: first I tried a contraction for the apostrophe ‘we wouldn’t’ - fail. Then I went for the possessive instead of the contraction, so ‘my mother’s’ worked.

– Mike Easter

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

https://www.arkansasonline.com/puzzles/quote/

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

The school is not the end but only the beginning of an education. Calvin Coolidge

Solving: I had more trouble than I should have because I made some kind of ‘mental misstep’ when I tried the ’the’ and decided it was wrong and so it took me much longer to accept that decryption than it should have. As a result, an early word was ‘school’ instead of ’the’.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

https://www.arkansasonline.com/puzzles/quote/

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

A business, like an automobile, has to be driven in order to get results. B.C. Forbes

The Forbes I am more familiar w/ is Malcolm, whose wp article is /much/ more interesting than Bertie’s. I hadn’t realized how opulent his life style was, I only knew about the personal Boeing 707 trijet ‘Capitalist Tool’. I also didn’t know he was a closet gay.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:

AK Q BEEH IDJSKCKW; IDJSKC KDBGSZ-ODXK VKWLKCS EO SGK SDYK. HKXKIEV SGK QWS EO IDJSKCDCB. - Q.Q. YECSQVKWS

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

Be a good listener; listen eighty-five percent of the time. Develop the art of listening. A.A. Montapert

Solving: ’the’ ’time’ ‘of’ ‘be a good’ ’listener’

How ’engineer-like’ to say ‘85%’ instead of ‘most’ or such.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

XQ EPNH PW XOH GVGHWX XOPZF PZ XOH YQGEL. UQWX JHQJEH HMPWX; XOVX PW VEE. - QWBVG YPELH

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

To live is the rarest thing in the world. Most people exist; that is all. Oscar Wilde

… says OW, the hedonist. OW treats his novel character Dorian Gray disparagingly, when DG’s moral corruption is actually not all that much worse than OW’s. I’m reminded of a friend who speaks disparagingly about character traits of others which are only slightly worse than his own.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

S GSC XJK ISQTE VK XSEVT KCT JKPQ KY HNYT JSE CKV INEBKDTQTI VJT DSHPT KY HNYT. - BJSQHTE ISQXNC

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

A man who dares to waste one hour of life has not discovered the value of life. Charles Darwin

That is ridiculous; I can’t believe CD actually believed that. However, the wp article sounds like CD needed to learn how to relax better, so maybe he tho’t everyone should be overworked to the point of stress-related illness, like he was.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Always be a first-rate version of yourself, instead of a second-rate version of somebody else. Judy Garland

Solving: ‘a’ ‘always’ ‘be’ ’else’ ‘somebody’ ‘second-rate’

JG was nom/ed for best actress in Judgment at Nuremberg, but Rita Moreno won for West Side Story; also JG didn’t win best actress for A Star is Born, instead losing to Grace Kelly in A Country Girl.

The wp article on JG has a long section titled ‘Artistry’ which goes on at great length about her voice as described by a number of experts on the matter.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

If you’re going to be able to look back on something and laugh about it, you might as well laugh about it now. Marie Osmond

Solving: I saw ‘if you’re going to be’ right away, so the rest was easy.

The article/s about Marie and the Osmond family is interesting. The TV show Donny & Marie ran from ‘76-‘79. Marie is currently 61.

– Mike Easter

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Strive to be a person of value, and success will undeniably follow. Nenci Rodriguez

I’m becoming convinced that the person or system which provides the CQs wants to call the puzzle solver’s attention to Latinas of very modest/ limited/ accomplishments.

I also find that there is someone who likes to enter quotes such as the above on their FB page.

Solving: ‘a’ ‘and’ ‘will’ ‘follow’ ’to’ ‘of’ ‘success’

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

It is impossible for you to go on as you were before, so you must go on as you never have. Cheryl Strayed

Interesting story in the wp. CS’s Wild book was the first Oprah Winfrey selection when she started her book club show in 2012, and of course that made it go ballistic as a NYT best seller for so many weeks. Renee Witherspoon has a knack for grabbing/ optioning/ stuff like that, so then she made the movie and its successes.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

The contemplation of beauty causes the soul to grow wings. Plato

Solving: ’the’ ’to’ ‘Plato’ ‘contemplation’

But I’m still struggling w/ the last step of the Jumble. Aha! Shapely bodies. I don’t know why I was having so much trouble w/ bodies. Partly because I didn’t know whether the two parts were ‘shapely’ for the first word or ‘shapes’ for the 2nd word.

– Mike Easter

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

My life has been a roller coaster ride, but somehow I’ve always been able to land on my feet and still play the guitar. Ace Frehley

Besides the AF article, wp has another on Kiss. I enjoy reading about the early years of such as AF and the ‘birth’ of the band. I didn’t realize that Kiss had 10 years ‘unmasked’. There is also a small wp entry for AF’s autobiography book.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

To be in love is to touch with a lighter hand. In yourself you stretch, you are well. Gwendolyn Brooks

The cq is part of a 32 line poem; I was going to post it here, but I didn’t like it that much.

GB ‘17-‘00 poet, author, and teacher. Winner of Pulitzer for Poetry book

  • the first African American to receive a Pulitzer Prize.

Her NYT obit is a pretty good article; but it may be behind a paywall for some, or alernatively one can defeat that w/ some tricks.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Barbecue may not be the road to world peace, but it’s a start. Anthony Bourdain

For those who seem to be gobsmacked by the suicide of someone who had as much going for him as AB, I would say that AB was unconventional in many ways, including his wife/female relationships thru’out his life. My theory is that he went into some kind of ‘death spiral’ over something unhappy to do w/ his current Asia Argento situation. The wp article isn’t very helpful on this matter; there are plenty of articles written on ‘What killed AB?’

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

No matter who you meet in life, you take something from them, positive or negative. Gary Allan

GA is a country music singer-songwriter, now 53. The wp article has some interesting tidbits about how he got started and his lack of success w/ marriages, divorcee x2, widower x1. His discography is sufficiently extensive that there is a separate article for that.

– Mike Easter

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Mike Easter wrote:

… or, not so prominent Latinas.

Today’s CQ:

Face challenges, fear, and frustration by seeking out knowledge and opportunities for growth. Fanny Mairena

FM’s ‘presence’ is largely on social media incl YT.

Solving: ‘by’ (two unique letters) ‘seeking out’ ‘knowledge’ ‘opportunities’ then the first part.

– Mike Easter

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Sometimes the biggest accomplishment in life is to find yourself. Luisa Fernanda Cicero

There is some ambiguity over the names Luisa Fernanda (wp entry) vs Luisa Fernanda CiCero (GarCía); I’m going to assume it is the latter:

It seems that the CQ selections are somewhat partial to ‘prominent Latinas’.

Solving: ’the’ ‘sometimes’ ‘accomplishment’

– Mike Easter

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Love and compassion are necessities, not luxuries. Without them, humanity cannot survive. Dalai Lama

Solving: Unusually slow to get started. I /eventually/ tried ’not’ and then found ‘cannot’. I had been thinking about ’s’ for the double letters, so ‘cannot’ led to ‘compassion’ and ’necessities’.

Re the 14th DL:

<NYT 2011> <wp Central Tibetan Administration, ie Tibetan Government in Exile>

… and then there are such as Taiwan & Hong Kong.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Artificial intelligence is devoid of intelligence because it is devoid of artifice. Jean Baudrillard

Solving: It seems to me that I had more trouble w/ that than I should have. I ‘stumbled onto’ ‘intelligence’ fairly early, but somehow I must’ve been making some kind of error because ‘artificial’ didn’t jump out at me at all. I had a hard time figuring out ‘of’ and ‘devoid’. I had recognized the similarity between ‘artifice’ and ‘artificial’ but it was still a problem. And contributing to the problem is that I don’t really ‘get’ Baudrillard.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

The work will wait while you show the child the rainbow, but the rainbow won’t wait while you do the work. Patricia Clifford

PC doesn’t have a wp page, but apparent she is a producer/ executive producer w/ a lot of credits for her productions.

Solving: ’the’ trying ‘won’t’ gave all of those ‘w/s’, then the rest.

– Mike Easter

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

It takes no compromise to give people their rights … it takes no money to respect the individual. Harvey Milk

Again, the wp article on HM is good and very extensive. Anyone who only knows the HM (and spinoffs) stories from the 2008 acclaimed film ‘Milk’ and not from having read any books or seen other docu/s should/could at least read the wp article to get the big picture. There is a lot in there that I didn’t know about HM’s evolution. Plus you can read about the assassination and trial in other articles.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Where people have no dreams and no hopes and aspirations, life becomes dull and a meaningless wilderness. Tommy Douglas

TD ‘04-‘86 was a .ca politician w/ some interesting views described in his wp article.

– Mike Easter

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Embrace your vulnerabilities, accept them, and forgive yourself. Angelica Monroy

AM doesn’t have a wp article. One gets hits on social media, which I don’t read. She and about 9 other Latinas wrote authored a book about ‘inspired Latinas’.

There’s more than one AM found on the internet

Solving: I tried a letter w/ a high frequency as an ’e’ and somehow I got ’embrace’ early, along w/ ‘accept’ then ‘your’ etc. I’m surprised I didn’t have more trouble.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

This world would be a whole lot better if we just made an effort to be less horrible to one another. Elliot Page

Solving: was incomplete. After I got the quote and the first name, I was left w/ ‘xAxE’ for the last name, which could be a lot of different things. So, I employed the alternative to use the quote and the first name in a general search engine to get a hit for the last name.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Embrace what you don’t know… because what you don’t know can become your greatest asset. Sara Blakely

Solving: ‘xxn’t’ ‘you’ ‘what you don’t know’ ‘greatest’ ‘asset’

The wp article does a good job of telling the story of how SB became a self-made millionaire. She found an ‘itch’ and she scratched it.

– Mike Easter

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

In difficult circumstances, always act on first impressions. Leo Tolstoy

Solving: I had a difficult time getting started. Eventually, in trying the ‘i’ I was able to see ‘difficult’ and then ‘impressions’ and ‘first’. I should make a ‘mental note’ of the fact that the 6 letter ‘always’ has the same 1st and 4th letters like the 6 letter ‘people’, but that ‘people’ also has the same 2nd & 6th letters. Of course there is a lot of difference in the frequencies of ‘p’ vs ‘a’ & ’e’.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

We must not allow other people’s limited perceptions to define us. Virginia Satir

VS ‘16-‘88 was a psychotherapist and author, particularly the field of family reconstruction therapy.

– Mike Easter

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

There are two lasting bequests we can give our children: one is roots, the other is wings. Hodding Carter

HC (‘07-‘72) was a newspaper editor and speech writer for JF Kennedy; he was moderate-progressive who somehow evolved from white supremacist to crusading for racial equality to ‘slow’ integration.

The wp credits HC w/ the above quote. Another quote reference had a lot more to say about the investigation of the source of the quote. Ronald Reagan mistakenly attributed the quote in one of his speeches.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Your past does not define who you are, it’s only muscle that you are building for your future. Mayra Rubio

MR doesn’t have a wp entry, just social & professional media. She’s a contributor to a book about prominent Latina/s.

– Mike Easter

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Don’t worry about failure; you only have to be right once. Drew Houston

DH is a young billionaire who co-created Dropbox.

This 2018 bizinsider article is much better than the wp article because it tells about how he and the Iranian co-founder got together at MIT.

https://www.businessinsider.com/how-drew-houston-created-dropbox-2018-1 The rise of Dropbox CEO Drew Houston, who just made the Forbes 400 after taking his company public

– Mike Easter

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Mike Easter wrote:

Not only that, but the long yellow slide rule also had a Ln line. If you are going to have logs, natural ones are nice.

That stuff is useful in analytic geometry, trig, calculus, & differential equations which math is prerequisite to some chemistry and physics courses, such as physical chemistry.

The P chem classes had some math majors in it, who had gone to some trouble of taking chemistry & physics course prerequisites just to take P chem for the ‘fun of’ its math. P chem was when I learned that I didn’t have nearly the math aptitude that I had tho’t I did up until then :-)

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Don’t sit down and wait for the opportunities to come. Get up and make them. Madam C.J. Walker

CJ has an interesting bio as an allegedly first black female self-made millionaire. Born in 1867 after the proclamation, she was born free, while her 5 older siblings were born as slave children. She did not have an easy time getting to her success in black cosmetics and hair care products and later her activism and philanthropy.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

There’s nothing wrong with you. There’s a lot wrong with the world you live in. Chris Colfer

Never heard of him. To my learning surprise, in 2011 he was named in the Time 100 list of the most influential people in the world. I’ve never seen even a single episode of Glee. He’s written lots of popular books I’ve never heard of. Oh well.

– Mike Easter

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Consistency in regard to opinions is the slow poison of intellectual life. Unknown

Other sources ascribe the quote, w/ some modification to (Sir) Humphry Davy, a significant scientist of the 18-19th century.

Consistency in opinion is the slow poison of intellectual life, the destroyer of its vividness and energy. Humphry Davy

A page full of his alleged quotes has this one I liked:

https://www.quotemaster.org/author/Humphry+Davy

Besides reading about HD’s numerous scientific achievements, I was struck by the reference to him as Cornish (why not British?) so I started reading about the history (and geography + geology) of Cornwall and importantly found a wp article on the culture of Cornwall.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Children have never been very good at listening to their elders, but they have never failed to imitate them. James Baldwin

I surprised myself at how quickly I solved that one; I saw ’never’ was wrong about ‘seen’ then ‘very’ then ‘have never been very good’ then ‘children’ and the rest. So I was fast on the CQ but slow on the jumble which usually takes only seconds.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

One way to prevent conversation from being boring is to say the wrong thing. Frank Sheen

FS 1897-1981 > was an Australian-born lawyer, Catholic writer, publisher,

I particularly liked the 2011 story in a Catholic magazine “The Prophet of Hyde Park: Secrets of a Street-Corner Evangelist” https://www.crisismagazine.com/2011/the-prophet-of-hyde-park-secrets-of-a-street-corner-evangelist

He was raised Methodist by his Presbyterian father and Catholic mother and declared himself Catholic; got his BA in Sydney (and law degree?)

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Mistakes are a fact of life. It is the response to the error that counts. Nikki Giovanni

What’s in a name? Her name is Yolande Cornelia “Nikki” Giovanni Jr. Her sister’s name is Gary. She’s a prominent black poet, writer, commentator, activist, and educator, now age 78.

– Mike Easter

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

God made the world round so we could never see too far down the road. Isak Denisen

ID was a pen name for Baroness Karen Christenze von Blixen-Finecke 1885-1962. … when it was the British East Indies

That was made into an Oscar winning film, as was her Babette’s Feast short story. The wp article on KB/ID is quite biographical and provides TONS of info on her medical story, TMI. It sounds as if much of her medical problems were a combination of some psychosomatic and way way too much ‘wrong’ medical treatment, particularly poisons for an alleged syphilis dx which was never confirmed.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Stay away from creative people, they have a problem for every solution. Albert Einstein

I was surprised to quickly see ‘stay away from’ then ‘people’ ’they’ and by then the rest was solved.

– Mike Easter

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

No disability or dictionary out there is capable of clearly defining who we are as a person. Robert M. Hensel

RMH’s website is a better source of info about him than the wp article. He also said, “I have a Disability yes thats true, but all that really means is I may have to take a slightly different path than you”.

RMH is wheelchair-bound because of limitations from a birth defect, spina bifida. He is a writer and poet, and also set a Ripley-Guinness record for the longest sustained wheelie of over 6 mi. Besides his website, when I turned to the Talk section of the wp article, I learned that he had initially written the article, inviting wp editing. He was also asked to carry the torch for the 2006 Asian Games.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Each of us feels that we are just a drop in the ocean, but the ocean would be less without that missing drop. Mother Teresa

Born Anjezë Gonxhe Bojaxhiu an Albanian in a part of the Ottoman Empire in 1910, which area is now North Macedonia, a successor state of Yugoslavia.

I’ll have to read some about the Balkan Wars to get from Ottoman Empire thru’ Serbian rule to Bulgaria to Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes back to Bulgaria to a constituent of communist Yugoslavia then to North Macedonia.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Almost synchronicity:

Yesterday in Dear Abby: A close friend of mine hadn’t been feeling well. After seeing her doctor for a full day of tests she met up with me and I listened to her concerns. Before I could stop myself, I blurted out, “God, I hope you don’t have cancer!” she became very upset because of my comment and made me feel guilty for even mentioning it.

Today’s CQ:

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

The world is a book, and those who do not travel read only a page. St. Augustine

SA was a 3-4th century ‘Christian father’ who wrote a lot and influenced a lot.

I see from the wp article that there is a significant gap in my insight into the history of Christianity; so I’m going to have to do some reading. SA didn’t start out as a Christian.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

He’s my friend who speaks well of me behind my back. Thomas Fuller

TF 17th century English churchman, historian, writer.

I had a very tough time getting anything going. I wanted the apostrophe to be it’s; when I finally got off that and let it be he’s, ‘all of a sudden’ who speaks well of me jumped out.

– Mike Easter

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Good communication is just as stimulating as black coffee, and just as hard to sleep after. Anne Morrow Lindbergh

AML

… so they married, she became an aviator, they did all kinds of significant aviation work together. Lots of stories follow the Lindberghs, the kidnapping, Nazi Germany, activism.

I suspect AML was a much better aviator (-trix?) than Amelia Earhart who was bold but not old.

– Mike Easter

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Clearly, then, the city is not a concrete jungle, it is a human zoo. Desmond Morris

wp:

Solving:then the not it is a city clearly concrete jungle

– Mike Easter

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

I am so clever that sometimes I don’t understand a single word of what I am saying. Oscar Wilde

Solving: tried ‘I am’ then ’that’ ‘what’ ‘don’t’ ‘sometimes’ ‘understand’

OW’s prosecution under Victorian laws was about ‘just’ homosexuality, which of course wouldn’t happen in today’s climate. But the homosexual community of the day included very much of his preying on ‘boys’ - youths in their early teens including such young male prostitutes. So, that youth abuse behavior would have gotten a lot harsher punishment today than OW was given in his time.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Too often travel, instead of broadening the mind, merely extends the conversation. Elizabeth Drew

Solving; ’too’ ’the’ ‘often’ ‘of’ ‘instead’ ‘broadening’ ‘mind’.

ED now 85 is a journalist writer, author of 14 political books. The wp article has links to a slew of CSPAN vids of her activities. She moderated the Dem nom debates for the ‘84 race.

– Mike Easter

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

The longer we dwell on our misfortunes, the greater is their power to harm us. Voltaire

V was the pen name of François-Marie Arouet, but he actually used many scores of different pen names in his numerous writings in his lifetime. The ‘derivation’ of how he created than name is uncertain and has several different possibilities.

The wp article on V is very interesting; I would commend it. T is too extensive to encapsulate here. The section on this story, for example:

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Half the fun of the travel is the esthetic of the lostness. Ray Bradbury

Solving: I struggled w/ that one quite a bit. My problem was based on the ’the’ test. I wanted the letters for ’the’ to be that, but it was causing me confusion in other places. For a while I couldn’t make out ‘ExTHETxx’. I also had trouble w/ testing ‘of’ because I didn’t recognize xxxF until I saw it was actually ‘HxxF’. I also struggled w/ ‘xOSTxESS’.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

The theater was created to tell people the truth about life and the social situation. Stella Adler

SA ‘01-‘92 was an actress and much more importantly, an acting teacher. The wp article goes into depth about how she was influenced by and then influenced others w/ Stanislavski and his method. Her schools still operate today in NYC & LA.

The article on her schools says:

That article also has a large list of notable alumni.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Every parting is a form of death, as every reunion is a type of heaven. Tryon Edwards

TE is best known for being ‘full of’ quotes.

Solving: Starting w/ a guess at ’every’ + ‘a’ ‘is’, I should have been quicker w/ ‘of’ to get ‘form’ and I was also slow with ’type’, how many words are xYxE? It didn’t just jump out at me as quickly as it should’ve.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

If you want to conquer fear, don’t sit home and think about it. Go out and get busy. Dale Carnegie

Another one of those motivational speakers and writers. How many billions have been made by the numerous such. Would you even check out a self-help book from the library? Much less spend money and time on it?

Solving was pretty easy, because I experimented w/ ‘if you want to’ and ‘don’t’ and that gave me a lot of ammunition, especially after Dale Carnegie popped out.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Science has never drummed up quite as effective a tranquilizing agent as a sunny spring day. W. Earl Hall

WEH doesn’t have a wp page, but he has a sentence in a wp article as the editor of the Mason City Globe-Gazette and statewide radio personality because Meredith Willson has a wp article. MW was the ‘real life’ persona of The Music Man movie and there were big doings at Mason City in 1962 for the release of the movie.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Always do your best. What you plant now, you will harvest later. Og Mandino

The wp article on OM describes an interesting story of his route to be a motivational speaker and writer. I suppose we should ‘accept’ that all of those books and speakers thru’ the ages have value, but I guess it depends on the individual doing the reading or listening.

For those who like to keep up w/ the browser wars, the latest report from statcounter is:

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

A creative man is motivated by the desire to achieve, not by the desire to beat others. Ayn Rand

Deciding what to say about AR was a puzzle in itself, since I decided to approach her from the philosopher angle. Her ideas have been embraced by libertarians and conservatives which I would consider myself with trace elements of liberalism.

I read The Fountainhead in hs, presumably my mother’s book, a ‘43 best seller and a ‘49 movie. When I was reading AR’s wp article, I wanted to ‘dissect’ the concept of philosophy, but then I decided I needed to sort the academic disciplines first.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

The test for whether or not you can hold a job should not be the arrangement of your chromosomes. Bella Abzug

BA ‘20-‘98 was NY atty and US rep for 3 terms but an activist for women’s and gay rights many more years than that.

She successfully battled breast cancer for years, but had heart surgery at 77 and died post op.

Solving; started w/ ’the’ then ’test’ then ‘for whether’ ‘or not’ and then there were enough letters to get the rest.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Time: That which man is always trying to kill, but which ends in killing him. Herbert Spencer

Solving: working w/ ’that’ puzzled over ‘which’ at first, tried ‘is’, tried ‘but’ tried ‘him’; that opened the door to ’time’ which gave me the ’e’ and I figured out ‘which’ and the ’e’ gave me Herbert Spencer and the rest.

The wp article on HS places him as a very important influence of his century; not only is the main article quite long, but so is the Talk section. The scuffles which develop in talk are often amusing in themselves. The section which takes issue over NPOV (neutral point of view which the wp is supposed to uphold) is particularly vigorous.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

The right to be let alone is indeed the beginning of all freedom. William O. Douglas

WD appt’d by FDR at 40 and served longest for 36 years on SCOTUS.

The GreyCat whose bash site was being discussed also cited a Thomas Jefferson quote in his arguments for open vs closed:

The business of ‘information wants to be free’ is obviously at odds w/ some copyright and intellectual property concepts, but sometimes that ‘stuff’ suffers an imbalance in which ‘we’ (by some metric of that word) suffer/ are deprived/ because the ‘freedom’ aspect is too limited. As an example, big pharma has to spend an enormous amount of money to make some types of progress, but for which they are rewarded ‘disproportionately’ (sometimes/often). The story becomes even more complex when it results in discrepancies between what various medical ’needs’ cost the uninsured private payer vs the cost to various 3rd party payers and the great ’non-transparency’ gap.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Obsessed by a fairy tale, we spend our lives searching for a magic door and a lost kingdom of peace. Eugene O’Neill

As is so often the case, I found myself casting about to see if there were some useful commentary on some context or other clue to what EON was talking about there.

One little clue said, ‘Stately Mansions’ 1964

Huh? 1964?!

So I went to see if the wp could tell me anything about that. Sure enough, it was something unfinished that EON did in ‘36-‘39 as a sequel that he did NOT want pub’d posthumously. But his widow did anyway, so it came out in ‘64.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Celebrate all the things you don’t like about yourself - love yourself. Lady Gaga

Solving: I tried the ‘all’ and ’the’ guessed the ’things’, wondered about the contraction ‘don’t’ (which turned out to be a single-letter error on the part of the encryptor) and then the rest came together.

I would have never otherwise read a wp article about Lady Gaga, but it had a number of interesting tidbits and it was even interesting to read her success story as someone not a fan.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Problems are not stop signs, they are guidelines. Robert H. Schuller

Solving; first I wondered if ‘are’ was ’the’, when I decided it wasn’t, I wondered if ‘are not’ would work and it did. Then I found Robert and ’they’ and it was done.

Reading articles of interest were those of RS, particularly early years from drive-in ministry to the Crystal Cathedral, its article, and the evolution of the leadership, bankruptcies, and now Roman Catholic Christ Cathedral, Diocese of Orange.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

I love spring anywhere, but if I could choose I would always greet it in a garden. Ruth Stout

I haven’t read any Ruth Stout gardening, but I’ve read a lot of bro Rex’s work. My mother also lived to age 96.

– Mike Easter

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

I’d take the awe of understanding over the awe of ignorance any day. Douglas Adams

DA is the author of The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy

The amount I knew about H2G2 could fit in a thimble. When I read the wp articles about DA and H2G2, I was surprised that I hadn’t heard more. It is unusual that I read science fiction; I’d heard the name Zaphod Beeblebox, but didn’t associate it w/ any image.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

We are all mortal until the first kiss and the second glass of wine. Eduardo Galeano

Not infrequently on CQ/s I wonder ‘What was that all about?’ because it may not stand all on its own if it came out of a larger context.

On this item, I was fortunate to find a blogger who is a fan of the EG book from which the CQ was taken and cared enough to provide the context for it; from The Fiesta section of The Book of Embraces:

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

I try to give people a different way of looking at their surroundings. That’s art to me. Maya Lin

ML b. ‘59; while a 21 y/o undergrad at Yale, won a nat’l competition in ‘81 for the design of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington, D.C.

The wp article on ML is of some interest related to her heritage, controversies surrounding the memorial, later works and recognition.

In ‘94, a documentary was made about her which won the Academy Award for Best Documentary Feature.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Once you bring life into the world, you must protect it. We must protect it by changing the world. Elie Wiesel

Last time I said something about EW, I posted a link to the wp article about his 1960 book Night.

It sounds to me like the book was a ‘slow-moving’ breakthrough for him. Decades later Oprah Winfrey spotlighted it in 2006. By then he had written a lot of books.

item.title: Re: Puzzle corner
item.description:
Today’s CQ:

Ambition is the path to success. Persistence is the vehicle you arrive in. Bill Bradley

BB has a lot of accomplishments; b’ball Olympic gold, pro basketball player, Rhodes scholar, successful politician US Sen + candidate for nom for prez, 7 non-fiction books.

There are probably some personal secrets related to having been married to a .de professor for 33 y, divorcing, and then ‘shacking up’ w/ a similarly aged LBJ Lib’y director.
